On Tue, 10 Jun 2003, Parker Thompson wrote:

||- Similarly, is the binary format in rfc2540 actually losing
||  anything from the raw DNS response packet -- should we 
||  perhaps archive that instead?
|
|
|To the best of my understanding no.  I did not encounter this in the
|documentation, but my understanding is that the DNS server passes a binary
|representation of the data to the transport layer (UDP), it is received
|and unwrapped as-is on the other side, moving back up into the application
|layer (the crawler).

To clarify a bit, the binary and text formats prescribed by RFC 2540 are
equivelent, though these do not represent all information contained in a
raw DNS message as defined by 1035.  DNS message headers will additionally
contain:

- A 16-bit identifier assigned by the program generating the query.
- Boolean is_query (or is_response)
- An opt code (standard query, inverse query, and server status request)
- Boolean is_authoritative
- Boolean was_truncated for truncated UDP messages
- Information about the server's ability to perform recersive operations
- A response code, as discussed earlier

Hope that makes things a bit more clear,

pt.
--
Parker Thompson
The Internet Archive
